instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00850: What is 820-00850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V3_G3H_RTC? PP3V3_G3H_RTC Is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS: What is PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS? PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS is 20v in from the USB-C charger on USB-C powered Macbook Pros..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> in power, there are no signs of oxidation.
threads.message:
hello friend I need your advice again lol
board voltages:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.38V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.31v
<SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_XB_VBUS</SIGNAL> 5.07V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_TB_LDO</SIGNAL> 3.36V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> 3.39V
<SIGNAL>PMU_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> 3.38v


I imagine that these voltages help to fix it;)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> in power, there are no signs of oxidation.
threads.message:
Looks like (already classic) T2 firmware corruption.
Already explained on the forum what to do...
[url]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/search?q=t2+firmware&searchJSON=%7B%22keywords%22%3A%22t2+firmware%22%7D[/url]
Good luck!
